positive.review: This is a tough one for me as this game creates a lot of love/hate relationships with people.  After years of playing ASE and now almost 2 years of ASA I can tell you I still love this game in single-player or PVE with friends.  It has an addictive game loop that keeps me coming back for every map release and the mod community is awesome despite some crap paid mods.  Alternatively, if you like PVP this game is a pay to win cesspool filled with cheaters that the devs can't or won't address.  The original Wildcard devs are well intentioned despite not being able to hit a release date if their lives depended on it, but Snail Games is the absolute poster-child for greedy, know nothing about gaming publishers that have all but ruined the gaming industry.  So if you like single-player or playing with a few friends then this game is worth full price - but don't buy it unless its on sale so we don't support this publisher on principle.  If you want a PVP dino game then I'd say you should stay far away and save your sanity.

ARK: Survival Ascended has a lot of potential, but it‚Äôs being held back by some frustrating issues. The updates are too frequent, too large, and take too long to download or install. What‚Äôs even more disappointing is that many of the same bugs from ARK: Survival Evolved are still here.

Yes, the graphics are definitely better ‚Äî the game looks amazing on a high-end machine. But if you don‚Äôt have powerful hardware, the improvement isn‚Äôt really worth the performance hit.

Another big problem is connection stability. Playing on a non-dedicated server often leads to frequent connection losses, which ruins the experience.

Overall, the experience is good, but it could easily be great if the developers focused more on optimization, stability, and fixing old issues instead of just releasing massive updates.

If your rig can handle it then I recommend getting it while it's on sale. It took a while for me to move over from Evolved but I quickly found that I liked a majority of the changes. 
I personally enjoy solo or small private servers* and recommend finding some nice QoL mods to make it even better. (I use Vanilla with sprinkles and Dino depot)
*Disclaimer: I do not, and never will, play on ARK's official servers. They are another world entirely.

I've been playing Ark: SE since release, and I don't mean full release, I mean way back in June of 2015. For die-hard fans of the lore and story, this is worth your time and money. For those looking for the classic PVP experience, I hate to say it but I'd steer away. I know both PVE and PVP very well for Ark, and towards the end of my journey with ASE i glided towards the PVE end of things, which made the game incredibly enjoyable and significantly less stressful especially with external responsibilities taking priority. I absolutely despise where Snail Games is taking this, and it's another example of "Absolutely DO NOT sell out for funding". Things get tight, we all understand that, but with a solid idea and passionate developers the community comes together to make a project happen. Before dragging this out, as a review, if you enjoy slow paced PVE, fun/drunken nights with friends clubbing dinosaurs, it's still the same game it was 10 years ago, just better looking, give it a try. Other than that, official servers are packed with hackers and unemployed people. I'll give it a positive review for nostalgia sake, but do not buy it thinking it is the next survival-crafting PVP arena.
It‚Äôs a great game, but its performance feels unoptimized relative to other Unreal Engine 5 games.

Ark: Survival Ascended isn‚Äôt just a remaster ‚Äî it‚Äôs a full-blown rebirth of one of the most ambitious survival games ever made. Built in Unreal Engine 5, this new version takes everything that made Ark: Survival Evolved iconic and breathes new life into it with jaw-dropping visuals, smarter AI, and an overall smoother, more immersive experience.

üî• Graphics & Performance

The first thing you‚Äôll notice is how gorgeous the game looks. Lush jungles, reflective water, dynamic lighting, and ultra-detailed dinosaurs ‚Äî every biome feels alive. Watching a T-Rex stomp through a misty forest at sunrise is breathtaking. While early builds had performance hiccups, recent patches have drastically improved optimization, and it now runs much smoother even on mid-tier rigs.

ü¶ñ Gameplay & Mechanics

All the classic survival elements return: crafting, building, taming, and fighting to stay alive against both the elements and other players. However, Ascended refines these systems. Building is more intuitive thanks to snap-point improvements and UI updates, and the revamped creature AI makes the world feel more dangerous and unpredictable.

The multiplayer experience is also far more stable than before, with crossplay and dedicated servers making it easier to join friends regardless of platform.

üéÆ Quality of Life Improvements

Studio Wildcard has clearly listened to the community. Inventory management is smoother, lighting and weather systems feel more natural, and the new interface feels modern without losing Ark‚Äôs distinctive grit.

Mod support is already thriving thanks to the new integrated mod browser, which makes installing and managing community creations effortless.

üåç Final Thoughts

Ark: Survival Ascended is everything fans wanted Ark to be ‚Äî a modern, stable, and visually spectacular version of the survival epic that started it all. It‚Äôs still brutal, still unpredictable, and still incredibly rewarding. Whether you‚Äôre a returning survivor or brand-new to the island, this is the best way to experience Ark.

Pros:

Unreal Engine 5 visuals are breathtaking

Improved building, UI, and AI

Strong mod support and crossplay

Massive potential for future content

Cons:

Occasional performance dips

Steep learning curve for newcomers

Verdict:

Ark: Survival Ascended isn‚Äôt just a remake ‚Äî it‚Äôs a redemption. The island has never felt more alive, dangerous, or beautiful.

I‚Äôve been playing ARK since ASE Early Access, and I fell in love with it right from the start ‚Äî even more after I discovered its story.
 There have been rough times, but also countless amazing ones.

I‚Äôve seen people say the game is still as buggy and laggy as it used to be, but honestly, that‚Äôs not so true anymore. I took a long break a few years ago and recently came back, and yes ‚Äî ARK still has its share of bugs and crashes ‚Äî but compared to what it used to be back in the day? It‚Äôs like night and day.

Some of you might not remember the times when baby maturation barely moved 1% in 24 hours on official servers, when the lag was so bad you couldn‚Äôt even reach your base door after 30 minutes, when cryopods would kill your tames instead of saving them, or when you logged in one morning only to find your dinos scattered all over the map. I lived through all of that ‚Äî and more.

Now, sure, my game still crashes occasionally and there‚Äôs the odd lag spike, but it‚Äôs nothing compared to those old days.

And to those who‚Äôve spent thousands of hours in ARK but still leave negative reviews ‚Äî if you really hated it that much, you wouldn‚Äôt have played it for so long. üòÑ ARK has flaws, but it‚Äôs still one of the best games I‚Äôve ever played ‚Äî and I‚Äôve played a lot.

I see many people complaining about paid DLCs or mods. I get it ‚Äî it‚Äôs not for everyone. But nobody‚Äôs forcing you to buy them. There are creatures I like too, but I don‚Äôt need to own them. I play without DLCs and mods and still have a great time ‚Äî and I know I‚Äôd enjoy it even if I did buy them.

Sure, Ninja Turtles and Power Rangers might be a bit over the top üòÖ, but again ‚Äî it‚Äôs your choice. Back in the day, ARK had none of this, and people still played it happily. It‚Äôs just an extra option now.

(For reference, I play on PvE servers ‚Äî I know that in PvP, paid creatures and talent trees might cause balance issues.)

So yeah ‚Äî I love ARK, even with all its imperfections, because it gives you something no other game can. If you‚Äôre a new player, don‚Äôt beg others for high-bred dinos. Start from scratch ‚Äî experience the struggle, the small victories, the full survival journey. That‚Äôs what makes ARK special, and you‚Äôll appreciate it so much more.

It can be both uplifting and frustrating ‚Äî and that‚Äôs exactly the point of a survival game.

The only thing I miss is the old official trade forums, where people traded in-game rather than for real money. But in the end, it‚Äôs always about the community ‚Äî and that‚Äôs what I miss most.

That‚Äôs all. Enjoy life, stay a little less negative ‚Äî because in the end, that negativity only hurts you. You‚Äôll realize it sooner or later. ü©∑

After more than two years, I decided to give this game a review.  Firstly, I am a huge fan of the ARK series, with several thousands of hours in ARK: Survival Evolved, and now running up at over 440 hours in Ascended.  Here are my thoughts for pros and cons, and then I'll wrap up with a value summary:

Cons:  At launch, it was a bit of a wreck when it came to crashes and optimization.  Unfortunately, to run the game on high details, you need a beefy system and to get a decent frame rate at those high details, you'll need to run Frame Generation or FSR.  I have a 4090, and another system with a 4080 Super.  Both run the game decently well, but require DLSS and Frame Gen to keep the game consistently above 100 FPS.  The crashes upon release were so frustrating that I wanted to put it on the shelf.  Simple stuff like accessing the inventory of a storage chest while in first person - CRASH!  That has all been resolved and today's ARK: Survival Ascended experience is one that is stable, and seems to be much better optimized.

Pros:  It feels just like ARK, but it looks incredible and no longer outdated like ARK: Survival Ascended.  They implemented a lot of QOL things into the game to make building easier, character models look MUCH better, and the updated sounds are just as impressive as the graphics.  My first experience in a cave was genuinely terrifying just because of the creepy ambient sounds echoing off of the walls of the cave.   Servers are easy to setup, and since they ditched that Nitrado stuff at the launch of the game, I'm very happy with how easy it is to setup and install mods on my own sever, and how easy it is for players to auto-download the mods when they join.  Quite simply, it's a far better experience than Survivor Evolved and the overhaul on mods was long overdue.

Overall summary:  While I understand that some may feel that this is a "re-skin" of an older game.  The reality is that it's not.  There was a ton of work that went into this game, and quite simply, it shows.  It wasn't perfect out of the gate, but I remind myself that sometimes we shouldn't let "perfect" be the enemy of "good".  It was good out of the gate, but had some issues, almost all of which are resolved.

If you are a member of the discord, you see the amount of regular updates the devs are releasing to both clients and servers.  This is not some fly-by-night cash grab push with devs not putting in the work.  They are!  If you don't believe it, go to the discord, run your own server, track all of the updates.  I'm actually very impressed with their dedication.  It shows that they want this to be a good product, and because of their dedication, it IS a good product.

Yes, it seemed at first that you were paying money to just get The Island, and what seemed to be an unfinished release ahead of the "ARK 2" pipe dream that we may never see, nor will we know if it's the game that many of us were looking to get as an official sequel.  In my mind, THIS game is the sequel.  It's everything we loved about the original ARK (for the most part - I'm sure some will have some things they loved about the first game that they are not getting here), but it's modernized in QOL, gameplay, graphics, and sound.  Now that most of my favorite maps have been released, I know I'm going to enjoy exploring them all over again in Ascended.  Similar to the orignal ARK, if you enjoy these games, you will easily recognize that the thousands of hours of enjoyment from the game, it easily exceeds the value you get when compared to AAA titles that offer you far less.

I recommend this game to new players looking for a fun (brutal to new players) sandbox game, old ARK players that have taken a break but want to dive back in, and to the haters that remained stubborn thinking the devs owed them a free game... come join us!

GET THIS, NOT ARK SURVIVAL EVOLVED! If you honestly cannot make up your mind between the two, I highly suggest getting this instead. It is full of dinosaurs, construction, and bosses. Please, if you like survival, building, crafting, dinosaurs, challenges, or just taming random animals, this is the game for you. This game is definitely my favorite game, no hesitation. Worth every penny.
